discovery project

research

The discovery project I aim to pursue aligns closely with my current research as an undergraduate in the CHAOS Lab, led by Principal Investigator Dr. Flavio Fenton and my mentor, Casey Lee-Trimble. Our lab specializes in the nonlinear dynamics of living systems, with a particular focus on the complex mechanisms underlying arrhythmias. Specifically, we study reentrant spiral waves—a dangerous subset of arrhythmias that can cause irregular heartbeats. Depending on their severity, these irregularities can disrupt blood circulation, depriving the brain and other organs of oxygen, potentially leading to severe complications or even death. Our research seeks to develop a robust computational model capable of predicting the behavior of these fibrillations, with the ultimate goal of advancing our understanding and treatment of life-threatening cardiac disorders.

problem

A major challenge in studying arrhythmias is the inconsistent generation of fibrillation in the lab. Previously, the process often involved excessively increasing or decreasing the heart rate—essentially "over-revving" or "under-revving" the heart until it failed. While this method can induce the specific type of fibrillation we aim to study, it is highly time-consuming and impractical, particularly since our experiments are conducted on ex-vivo hearts with limited viability. The only reliable way to trigger fibrillation using this approach is by gradually adjusting the heart rate to below 60 beats per minute or above 100 beats per minute. However, this gradual pacing weakens the heart's action potentials, further shortening its lifespan. To address this limitation, we need a more efficient mechanism or protocol that can rapidly induce fibrillation, maximizing the available experimental time to study arrhythmic behavior more effectively.

experiment

To develop a more consistent method for inducing fibrillation, we can take a two-step approach. The first step involves refining the technique by leveraging the symmetry of action potentials as they propagate through cardiac tissue. An action potential is initiated when the membrane potential reaches -70 mV, becoming unstoppable once it crosses the -55 mV threshold. The cell then rapidly depolarizes to approximately +30 mV before repolarizing back to -70 mV. A crucial aspect of this process is the recovery phase—when the tissue has not yet fully recovered from the previous action potential. By strategically introducing another action potential within this recovery period, we can disrupt the natural symmetry of wave propagation. This forced excitation causes the wave to reenter previously activated tissue, leading to the formation of a reentrant spiral wave—a hallmark of arrhythmias. This phenomenon can be artificially induced by precisely timing electrical stimulation at different locations in the cardiac tissue, effectively triggering an arrhythmia in the ventricular region of the heart.

progress

To automate this procedure I used an arduino microcontroller capable of applying about 3.3V to the tissue extending out of two electrodes that fire at different times. This creates asymmetry in the tissue and leads to an arrhythmia. We found this to be onducted on human hearts. This however is promising as a protocol to generate fibrillation once took minutes to an hour, now takes 20 seconds. The next goal is to take this rudimentary design and amplify its voltage to allow for human hearts and to upgrade the design to abandon the breadboard and permanently add components to a perfboard.
